:The Chesapeake Bay Institute,
a division of Hopkins devoted
solely to research in
oceanography, will soon be
vacating McCauley Hall at
Homewood and moving to the
Inner Harbor of Baltimore.
According to Dr. Jerry
Schubel, Assistant Director of
CBI, this will stimulate extra
freedom and flexibility for the
programs for the Institute.
"We're going to become an
off-campus institute, but we will
still be part of Hopkins," said
Schubel.
This action represents only
part of a dynamic history which
the Institute has had since its
founding in 1948.

completed to house the activities

Federal government and the
National Science Foundation. In

Robert B. Pond wins teaching award
Robert B. Pond Sr., professor
of metallurgy and chairman of

and Materials Science at the

Albert Easton White
Distinguished Teacher Award of
the American Society for Metals.
The award. which will be
presented at the Society's
National Awards and Fellow
Convocation in Detroit next
October, honors Pond in
recognition of "unusually long
and devoted service in the
teaching of metallurgy
characterized by ability to inspire
and impart enthusiasm to
students as well as by
metallurgical accomplishments."
As an addiiional honor. Pond
has been elected a Fellow of the
Society because of his
"distinguished contributions in
the fields of. metals and
materials." as well as receiving
the 1974 Award of Merit for his
"long and outstanding service to
the Baltimore Chapter of the
American Society for Metals."
Holder of a bachelor's degree
in Metallurgical Engineering from
Virginia Polytechnic Institute.
Pond has risen to the rank of full
professor and is viewed as the

country's spokesman. for this
field of science.
Pond claims to have developed
his interest in metal formation
while serving in the Navy where
he was involved with plate metal
production. "There is a kind of
religion in metals, an order and
structure that is indescribable,"
he said

enjoyment with teaching on this
subject. "Kids are the most
important thing in the world, and

given more than 230 "Fun in

audiences in the U.S. and
Canada. "Fun in Metals" has
been made into a film and is
distributed by the American
Society for Metals.
Pond has also lectured to
numberous professional groups,
including the First International
Conference of the Science and
Technology of Iron and Steel,
held in Tokyo. He holds a

number of patents in the field of
continuous casting of metals and
has published numerous technical
articles.

Society for Metals, Pond is
currently a member and past
president of the Maryland
Institute of Metals. He has served
on several national committees,
such as the National Committee
for Space Lab Experiments, and
in 1967 received the Society's
President Award.

Robert B. Pond wins teaching award
Robert B. Pond Sr., professor
of metallurgy and chairman of
the Department of Mechanics
and Materials Science at the
Homewood campus has been
named recipient of the 1974
Albert Easton White
Distinguished Teacher Award of
the American Society for Metals.
The award. which will be
presented at the Society's
National Awards and Fellow
Convocation in Detroit next
October, honors Pond in
recognition of "unusually long
and devoted service in the
teaching of metallurgy
characterized by ability to inspire
and impart enthusiasm to
students as well as by
metallurgical accomplishments."
As an addiiional honor. Pond
has been elected a Fellow of the
Society because of his
"distinguished contributions in
the fields of. metals and
materials." as well as receiving
the 1974 Award of Merit for his
"long and outstanding service to
the Baltimore Chapter of the
American Society for Metals."
Holder of a bachelor's degree
in Metallurgical Engineering from
Virginia Polytechnic Institute.
Pond has risen to the rank of full
professor and is viewed as the

country's spokesman. for this
field of science.
Pond claims to have developed
his interest in metal formation
while serving in the Navy where
he was involved with plate metal
production. "There is a kind of
religion in metals, an order and
structure that is indescribable,"
he said
Pond has also expressed his
enjoyment with teaching on this
subject. "Kids are the most
important thing in the world, and

I like to teach them." He has
given more than 230 "Fun in
Metals" lectures to high school
audiences in the U.S. and
Canada. "Fun in Metals" has
been made into a film and is
distributed by the American
Society for Metals.
Pond has also lectured to
numberous professional groups,
including the First International
Conference of the Science and
Technology of Iron and Steel,
held in Tokyo. He holds a

number of patents in the field of
continuous casting of metals and
has published numerous technical
articles.
A member of the American
Society for Metals, Pond is
currently a member and past
president of the Maryland
Institute of Metals. He has served
on several national committees,
such as the National Committee
for Space Lab Experiments, and
in 1967 received the Society's
President Award.

Water Polo Joins NCAA
A new team has joined the
realm of intercollegiate athletics
at Hopkins. The Blue Jay Water
Polo team has joined the NCAA
and will begin play in September.
They will be playing varsity
water polo at a club level.
Entering the Eastern Water Polo
Conference, the Homewood
aquamen will be competing with
the likes of Yale, Fordham,
Army, Syracuse and other
Eastern powers. Prior to the
upcoming season, the polomen
competed at a club level and last
season was highlighted by a
major win over Brown. Starting
next year they will be assisted by
a fulltime coach and an increased
schedule including numerous
away trips. Led by captain Curt
Gibbs, the team includes Sid
Mack, Steve Wright, and
freshman Doug Milligan, Rick

Goodall and Matt Laskowski.
They have been practicing this
spring and urge all good
swimmers interested to contact
Curt at 467-9364. There will be a
water polo match this Friday
night at 7:30 against Villanova in
Homewood pool. Admission is
free.
